Conservative Party of Ontario|PC]]) }} |timezone = [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |utc_offset = −5 |timezone_DST = [[Eastern Daylight Time|EDT]] |utc_offset_DST = −4 }} '''London''' is a city located in [[Southwestern Ontario]], [[Canada]] along the [[Quebec City–Windsor Corridor]]. The city has a population of 366,151 according to the [[Canada 2011 Census|2011 Canadian census]]. London is at the confluence of the non-navigable [[Thames River (Ontario)|Thames River]], approximately halfway between [[Toronto]], Ontario and [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. The City of London is a separated municipality, [[List of Ontario separated municipalities|politically separate]] from [[Middlesex County, Ontario|Middlesex County]], though it remains the county seat. London and the Thames were named in 1793 by [[John Graves Simcoe]], who proposed the site for the capital of [[Upper Canada]]. The first European settlement was between 1801 and 1804 by Peter Hagerman.{{cite book|author=St-Denis, Guy|title=Byron:Pioneer Days in Westminster Township|publisher=Crinklaw Press|year=1985|isbn=0-919939-10-4|pages=21–22}} The village was founded in 1826 and [[Municipal corporation|incorporated]] in 1855. Since then, London has grown to be the largest Southwestern Ontario municipality and Canada's 11th largest municipality, having annexed many of the smaller communities that surrounded it. London is a regional centre of health care and education, being home to the [[University of Western Ontario]], [[Fanshawe College]], and several hospitals. The city hosts a number of musical and artistic exhibits and festivals, which contribute to its tourism industry, but its economic activity is centred on education, medical research, [[insurance]], and [[information technology]]. London's university and hospitals are among its top ten employers. London lies at the junction of [[Ontario Highway 401|Highway 401]] and [[Ontario Highway 402|402]], connecting it to Toronto, Windsor, and [[Sarnia]]. It also has an [[London International Airport|international airport]], train and bus station. == History == === Founding === Prior to European contact in the 18th century, the present site of London was occupied by several [[Neutral Nation|Neutral]] and [[Odawa people|Odawa]]/[[Ojibwa]] villages. Archaeological investigations in the region indicate that [[aboriginal peoples in Canada|aboriginal]] people have resided in the area for at least the past 10,000 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.civilization.ca/cmc/archeo/emercury/159.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930050430/http://www.civilization.ca/cmc/archeo/emercury/159.htm |archivedate=30 September 2007 |title=An Early Paleo-Indian Site near Parkhill, Ontario |last=Ellis |first=Christopher |author2=Deller, D Brian |publisher=ASC Publications|accessdate=24 September 2009}} The current location of London was selected as the site of the future capital of [[Upper Canada]] in 1793 by [[Lieutenant governor|Lieutenant-Governor]] [[John Graves Simcoe]]. Simcoe intended to name the settlement ''Georgina'',{{cite book| title=History of Toronto and County of York, Ontario: Containing an Outline of the History of the Dominion of Canada; a History of the City of Toronto and the County of York, with the Townships, Towns, General and Local Statistics; Biographical Sketches (Part II: The County of York)| last1=Adam| first1=Graeme Mercer| last2=Mulvany| first2=Charles Pelham| last3=Robinson| first3=Christopher Blackett| volume=1| page=9| publisher=C.B. Robinson| year=1885}} in honour of [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George III]], and renamed the river. However, the choice of a capital site in the midst of extensive hardwood forests was rejected by [[Guy Carleton, 1st Baron Dorchester|Guy Carleton (Governor Dorchester)]].{{cite book| last=Spelt| first=J| title=Urban development in south-central Ontario| publisher=McClelland and Stewart| year=1972}} In 1814, there was a skirmish during the [[War of 1812]] in what is now southwest London at Reservoir Hill, formerly Hungerford Hill.{{cite web| url=http://www.ul.london.on.ca/urbanweb/News/News2005/OMBreservoirhill.pdf| title=Reservoir Hill| date=February 2001| publisher=Ontario Municipal Board| page=40| accessdate=24 September 2009}} The village of London, named after the English capital of [[London]],{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2LAEAQAAIAAJ&q=%22named+after+london%22%22London,+Ontario+%22&dq=%22named+after+london%22%22London,+Ontario+%22 |title=Canada: wonderland of surprises|author1=Max Braithwaite |publisher=Dodd, Mead|year=1967 }} was not founded until 1826, and not as the [[Capital (political)|capital]] Simcoe envisioned. Rather, it was an administrative seat for the area west of the actual capital, [[York, Upper Canada|York]] (now Toronto). Locally, it was part of the [[Talbot Settlement]], named for Colonel [[Thomas Talbot (Upper Canada)|Thomas Talbot]], the chief coloniser of the area, who oversaw the land surveying and built the first [[Government Buildings|government buildings]] for the administration of the Western Ontario peninsular region. Together with the rest of Southwestern Ontario, the village benefited from Talbot's provisions, not only for building and maintaining roads, but also for assignment of access priorities to main routes to productive land.{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/About_London/london_history.htm|title=The beginnings| year=2009| publisher=City of London| accessdate=24 September 2009}} At the time, Crown and [[clergy reserve]]s were receiving preference in the rest of Ontario. In 1832, the new settlement suffered an outbreak of [[cholera]].{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/About_London/timeline1-2.htm| title=Event Highlights for the City of London 1793–1843| publisher=City of London| accessdate=24 September 2009}} London proved a centre of strong [[Tory]] support during the [[Upper Canada Rebellion]] of 1837, notwithstanding a brief rebellion led by [[Charles Duncombe (Upper Canada Rebellion)|Charles Duncombe]]. Consequently, the British government located its Ontario peninsular garrison there in 1838, increasing its population with soldiers and their dependents, and the business support populations they required. London was incorporated as a town in 1840. On 13 April 1845, fire destroyed much of London, which was at the time largely constructed of wooden buildings.{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/About_London/timeline3.htm| title=Event Highlights for the City of London 1844–1894| publisher=City of London| accessdate=24 September 2009}} One of the first casualties was the town's only [[fire engine]]. This fire burned nearly 30 acres of land destroying 150 buildings before burning itself out later the same day. One-fifth of London was destroyed and this was the province's first million dollar fire.{{cite book| first=Bill| last=Adams| title=The History of the London Fire Department of heroes, helmets and hoses| publisher=London Fire Department| edition=1st| year=2002| page=13| isbn=0-9732159-0-9}} On 1 January 1855, London was incorporated as a "city" (10,000 or more residents). In the 1860s, a sulphur spring was discovered at the forks of the Thames River while industrialists were drilling for [[Petroleum|oil]].{{cite web| url=http://www.londonhistory.org/bath.htm| accessdate=2 June 2008| title=Ontario White Sulphur Springs| publisher=The London and Middlesex Historical Society}} The springs became a popular destination for wealthy Ontarians, until the turn of the 20th century when a [[textiles|textile]] [[factory]] was built at the site, replacing the spa. Long before the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] was established in 1876, there were proposals for military colleges in Canada. Staffed by British Regulars, adult male students underwent a 3 month long military courses from 1865 at the School of Military Instruction in London. Established by Militia General Order in 1865, the school enabled Officers of Militia or Candidates for Commission or promotion in the Militia to learn Military duties, drill and discipline, to command a Company at Battalion Drill, to Drill a Company at Company Drill, the internal economy of a Company and the duties of a Company's Officer.[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~theislands/photos6/ansonkeillmilcert.jpg Anson Keill's Second class certificate from the School of Military Instruction, Kingston] The school was not retained at Confederation, in 1867.Richard Preston 'Canada's RMC: A History of the Royal Military College of Canada' published by the RMC Club by U of Toronto Press. === Development === [[File:Blackfriars Bridge WPC.JPG|left|thumb|upright|Blackfriars Street Bridge]] Sir [[John Carling]], Tory MP for London, gave three events to explain the development of London in a 1901 speech. They were: the location of the court and administration in London in 1826; the arrival of the military garrison in 1838; and the arrival of the railway in 1853.{{cite book| last=Lutman| first=John| title=The Historic Heart of London| publisher=Corporation of the City of London| year=1977| page=6}} In 1875, London's first iron bridge, the [[Blackfriars Street Bridge]], was constructed. It replaced a succession of flood-failed wooden structures that had provided the city's only northern road crossing of the river. A rare example of a bowstring [[truss bridge]], the Blackfriars remains open to pedestrian and bicycle traffic, though it is currently closed indefinitely to vehicular traffic due to various structural problems.{{cite news| url=http://blackburnnews.com/london/2013/12/19/blackfriars-bridge-opens-to-pedestrians/ |title=Blackfriars Bridge Open To Pedestrians |first=Avery |last=Moore |publisher=Blackburn News |date=19 December 2013 |accessdate=3 March 2014}} The Blackfriars, amidst the river-distance between the [[Carling]] Brewery and the historic [[Labatt Park|Tecumseh Park]] (including a major mill), linked London with its western suburb of Petersville, named for Squire Peters of Grosvenor Lodge. That community joined with the southern subdivision of Kensington in 1874, formally incorporating as the municipality of Petersville. Although it changed its name in 1880 to the more inclusive "London West", it remained a separate municipality until ratepayers voted for amalgamation with London in 1897, largely due to repeated flooding. The most serious flood was that of July 1883, which resulted in serious loss of life and property devaluation.{{cite thesis|last=Stott| first=Gregory| title=The Maintenance of Suburban Autonomy: The Story of the Village of Petersville-London West, Ontario, 1874–1897| degree=MA| publisher=University of Western Ontario| year=1999| chapter=Four}} This area retains much original and attractively maintained 19th-century tradespeople's and workers' housing, including [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] cottages as well as larger houses, and a distinct [[sense of place]]. [[File:London-OntarioChurch1.jpg|right|thumb|upright|[[St. Peter's Cathedral Basilica, London|St. Peter's Cathedral Basilica]], seat of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of London]] ]] [[File:Victoria Park WWI statue06.jpg|left|thumb|upright|London's [[Boer War]] statue, Victoria Park]] [[File:London Ontario Urban Sprawl.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Urban sprawl]] in suburban London]] London's eastern suburb, London East, was (and remains) an industrial centre, which also incorporated in 1874. Attaining the status of town in 1881,{{cite web| url=http://council.london.ca/meetings/Archives/Agendas/Planning%20Committee%20Agendas/Planning%20Committee%20Agendas%202004/2004-08-30%20Agenda/Item%209b.pdf| title=Item 9b| publisher=London Advisory Committee on heritage| accessdate=25 September 2009}} it continued as a separate municipality until concerns over expensive waterworks and other fiscal problems led to amalgamation in 1885.{{cite web| url=http://www.londonhistory.org/Londoneast.htm| title=London East| last=Wilson| first=Robert| publisher=London and Middlesex Historical Society| accessdate=25 September 2009}} The southern suburb of London, including Wortley Village, was collectively known as "London South". Never incorporated, the South was annexed to the city in 1890, although Wortley Village still retains a distinct [[sense of place]]. By contrast, the settlement at Broughdale on the city's north end had a clear identity, adjoined the university, and was not annexed until 1961.{{cite web| url=http://broughdale.ca/|title=Broughdale Community Association| publisher=BCA| accessdate=25 September 2009}} On 24 May 1881, the [[ferry]] ''SS Victoria'' capsized in the Thames River, [[drowning]] approximately 200 passengers, the worst disaster in London's history. Two years later, on 12 July 1883, the first of the two most devastating floods in London's history killed 17 people. The second major flood, on 26 April 1937, destroyed more than a thousand houses and caused over $50 million in damages, particularly in West London.{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/About_London/timeline6.htm| title=Event Highlights for the City of London 1930–1949| publisher=City of London| accessdate=25 September 2009}}{{cite web| url=http://ontario.hazards.ca/historical/Flood_Ontario-e.html|title=Historical Flood-Related Events| date=18 February 2009| publisher=Environment Canada| accessdate=21 October 2009}} After repeated floods the [[Upper Thames River Conservation Authority]] in 1953 built Fanshawe Dam on the North Thames to control the downstream rivers.{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/About_London/timeline7.htm| title=Event Highlights for the City of London 1950–1959| publisher=City of London| accessdate=25 September 2009}} Financing for this project came from the federal, provincial, and municipal governments. Other [[natural disaster]]s include a 1984 [[tornado]] that led to damage on several streets in the White Oaks area of South London.{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/About_London/timeline.htm| title=Event Highlights for the City of London 1980–1989| publisher=City of London| accessdate=25 September 2009}} London's role as a military centre continued into the 20th century during the two [[World War]]s, serving as the administrative centre for the Western Ontario district. In 1905, the London Armoury was built and housed the First Hussars until 1975. A private investor purchased the historic site and built a new hotel (Delta London Armouries, 1996)in its place preserving the shell of the historic building. In the 1950s, two reserve battalions amalgamated and became [[3 Royal Canadian Regiment|London and Oxford Rifles (3rd Battalion), The Royal Canadian Regiment]].{{cite web| url=http://www.army.forces.gc.ca/land-terre/units-unites/index-eng.asp?action=City&id=39&rid=267#267| title=London, Ontario| publisher=Department of National Defence| accessdate=25 September 2009}} This unit continues to serve today as 4th Battalion, [[The Royal Canadian Regiment]]. The Regimental Headquarters of [[The Royal Canadian Regiment]] remains in London at Wolseley Barracks on Oxford Street. The barracks are home to the First Hussars militia regiment as well. === Annexation to present === London [[annexation|annexed]] many of the surrounding communities in 1961, including [[Byron, Ontario|Byron]] and Masonville, adding 60,000 people and more than doubling its area. After this amalgamation, suburban growth accelerated as London grew outward in all directions, creating expansive new subdivisions such as Westmount, Oakridge, Whitehills, Pond Mills, White Oaks and Stoneybrook. In 1992, London annexed nearly the entire township of [[Westminster, Middlesex County, Ontario|Westminster]], a large, primarily [[rural municipality]] directly south of the city, including the [[police village]] of [[Lambeth, Middlesex County, Ontario|Lambeth]].{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/About-London/london-history/Pages/1977-to-2000.aspx| title=History of London - 1977 to 2000| publisher=City of London| accessdate=21 January 2015}} With this massive annexation, London almost doubled in area again, adding several thousand more residents. London now stretches south to the boundary with [[Elgin County]]. The 1993 annexation made London one of the largest urban municipalities in Ontario.{{cite news| url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:s9hkV_RIV10J:www.lfpress.ca/cgi-bin/publish.cgi%3Fp%3D220108%26s%3Dsociete+%22did+annexation+work%3F%22&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=ca| title=Did Annexation Work?| last=Martin| first=Chip| date=29 December 2007| work=Special Report| publisher=London Free Press}} Intense commercial and residential development is presently occurring in the southwest and northwest areas of the city. Opponents of this development cite [[urban sprawl]],{{cite web| url=http://www.ul.london.on.ca/urbanweb/Links/UrbanPlanning/index.htm| title=New Directions in Urban Planning| publisher=Urban League of London| accessdate=25 September 2009}} destruction of rare [[Carolinian zone]] forest and farm lands,{{cite web| url=http://www.ul.london.on.ca/urbanweb/ActiveCitizen/ESA/index.htm| title=Environmentally Significant Areas| year=2006| publisher=Urban League of London| accessdate=25 September 2009}} replacement of distinctive regions by generic malls, and standard transportation and pollution concerns as major issues facing London. The City of London is currently the [[List of the 100 largest urban areas in Canada by population|eleventh-largest urban area in Canada]], [[List of the 100 largest metropolitan areas in Canada|eleventh-largest census metropolitan area in Canada]], and the sixth-largest city in Ontario.{{cite web| url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2006/dp-pd/hlt/97-550/Index.cfm?TPL=P1C&Page=RETR&LANG=Eng&T=205&SR=1&S=3&O=D&RPP=33| title=Population and dwelling counts, for census metropolitan areas, 2006 and 2001 censuses: 100% data| date=19 December 2008| publisher=Statistics Canada| accessdate=21 October 2009}}{{cite web| url=http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/popdwell/Table.cfm?T=801&PR=0&SR=1&S=3&O=D| title=Population and dwelling counts, for urban areas, 2006 and 2001 censuses: 100% data| date=5 November 2008| publisher=Statistics Canada| accessdate=21 October 2009}} == Geography == The area was formed during the retreat of the [[glacier]]s during the [[Quaternary glaciation|last ice age]], which produced areas of [[marshland]], notably the [[Sifton Bog]] (which is actually a [[fen]]), as well as some of the most agriculturally productive areas of farmland in Ontario.{{cite web| url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?Params=A1ARTA0005936&PgNm=TCE| title=Ontario| year=2009| publisher=Historica-Dominion| accessdate=25 September 2009}} The Thames River dominates London's geography. The North and South branches of the Thames River meet at the centre of the city, a location known as "The Forks" or "The Fork of the Thames."{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/Parks_and_Natural_Areas/Parks_guide.htm| title=Your Guide to London's Major Public Parks & Gardens| publisher=City of London| accessdate=25 September 2009}} The North Thames runs through the man-made Fanshawe Lake, located in northeast London. Fanshawe Lake was created by Fanshawe Dam, constructed to protect the downriver areas from the catastrophic flooding which affected the city in 1883 and 1937.{{cite web| url=http://www.thamesriver.on.ca/Water_Management/Fanshawe_Dam.htm| title=Fanshawe Dam| publisher=Upper Thames River Conservation Authority| accessdate=25 September 2009}} === Climate === [[File:LONDONMORNING.jpg|thumb|left|Downtown London on a winter morning in January 2011]] London has a [[humid continental climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification|Köppen]] ''Dfb''), though due to its downwind location relative to Lake Huron and elevation changes across the city, it is virtually on the Dfa/Dfb (hot summer) boundary favouring the former climate zone to the southwest of the confluence of the South and North Thames Rivers, and the latter zone to the northeast (including the airport). Because of its location in the continent, London experiences large [[seasonal]] contrast, tempered to a point by the surrounding [[Great Lakes]]. The summers are usually warm to hot and humid, with a July average of {{convert|20.8|C|1}}, and temperatures above {{convert|30|C}} occur on average 10 days per year. In 2016, however, temperatures at or above {{convert|30|C}} occurred more than 35 times. The city is affected by frequent thunderstorms due to hot, humid summer weather, as well as the [[Convergence zone|convergence of breezes]] originating from [[Lake Huron]] and [[Lake Erie]]. The same convergence zone is responsible for spawning funnel clouds and the occasional tornado. London is located in Canada's [[Tornado Alley]]. Spring and autumn in between are not long, and winters are cold but witness frequent thaws. Annual precipitation averages {{convert|1011.5|mm|in|2|abbr=on}}. Its winter snowfall totals are heavy, averaging about {{convert|194|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} per year. The majority of it comes from [[lake effect snow]] and [[snow squalls]] originating from Lake Huron, some {{convert|60|km||abbr=on|0}} to the northwest, which occurs when strong, cold winds blow from that direction. From 5 December 2010, to 9 December 2010, London experienced record snowfall when up to {{convert|2|m|in|0||abbr=on}} of snow fell in parts of the city. Schools and businesses were closed for three days and bus service was cancelled after the second day of snow.{{cite news| url=http://www.lfpress.com/news/london/2010/12/07/16460466.html| accessdate=5 April 2012|title=It's one for the history books|newspaper=London Free Press| last=Daniszewski| first=Hank| date=7 December 2010}} The highest temperature ever recorded in London was {{convert|41.1|C|0}} on 6 August 1918. {{cite web | url = http://climate.weather.gc.ca/climate_data/daily_data_e.html?hlyRange=%7C&dlyRange=1883-03-01%7C1932-01-31&mlyRange=1883-01-01%7C1932-12-01&StationID=4792&Prov=ON&urlExtension=_e.html&searchType=stnName&optLimit=yearRange&StartYear=1840&EndYear=2016&selRowPerPage=25&Line=7&searchMethod=contains&txtStationName=london&timeframe=2&Year=1918&Month=8 | title = August 1918 | work = Canadian Climate Data | publisher = Environment Canada | accessdate = 21 March 2016}} The lowest temperature ever recorded was {{convert|-32.2|C|0}} on 20 January 1892. {{cite web | url = http://climate.weather.gc.ca/climate_data/daily_data_e.html?hlyRange=%7C&dlyRange=1883-03-01%7C1932-01-31&mlyRange=1883-01-01%7C1932-12-01&StationID=4792&Prov=ON&urlExtension=_e.html&searchType=stnName&optLimit=yearRange&StartYear=1840&EndYear=2016&selRowPerPage=25&Line=7&searchMethod=contains&Month=1&Day=13&txtStationName=london&timeframe=2&Year=1892 | title = January 1892 | work = Canadian Climate Data | publisher = Environment Canada | accessdate = 21 March 2016}} {{Weather box |location = London, Ontario ([[London International Airport]]), 1981−2010 normals, extremes 1871−present{{efn|London's long term climate record has been recorded at various climate stations in or near the city of London since 1871. Other religions include [[Islam]] (4.4%), [[Buddhism]] (0.8%), [[Hinduism]] (0.8%), and [[Judaism]] (0.5%), with 29.9 percent of the population reporting no religious affiliation. According to the 2011 census, 82.0 percent of the population of London are [[Ethnic groups in Europe|European]], 2.7 percent are [[Latin American]], 2.6 percent are [[Arab people|Arab]], 2.4 percent are [[Black Canadians|Black]], 2.2 percent are [[South Asian Canadian|South Asian]], 2.0 percent are [[Chinese Canadian]], 1.9 percent are [[Aboriginal Peoples in Canada|Aboriginal]], 1.0 percent are [[Southeast Asia]]n, 0.8 percent are [[West Asia]]n, 0.8 percent are [[Korean people|Korean Canadian]], 0.6 percent are [[Filipino Canadians|Filipino]], and 0.7 percent belong to other groups. In the 2011 census, the predominant ethnic origins of Londoners were English (30.5%), Canadian (26.0%), Scottish (20.8%), Irish (20.3%), German (11.5%), French (10.1%), Dutch (6.2%), Italian (4.7%), Polish (4.4%), Portuguese (2.8%), and Ukrainian (2.5%). In February 2015, Statistics Canada published a population estimate of the London CMA of 502,360, as of July 1, 2014.{{cite web|title=Table 1- Annual population estimates by census metropolitan area, July 1, 2014|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/150211/t150211a001-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|accessdate=18 August 2015}} == Economy == [[File:London Ontario Skyline Panorama.jpg|thumb|left|Panorama of the London Skyline viewed from [[Brescia University College]] at the [[University of Western Ontario]]]] London's economy is dominated by [[medical]] research, [[insurance]], [[manufacturing]], and [[information technology]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} Much of the [[life sciences]] and [[biotechnology]]-related research is conducted or supported by the University of Western Ontario, which adds about [[Canadian dollar|C$]]1.5 billion to the London economy annually.{{cite web|url=http://www.servicecanada.gc.ca/eng/on/offices/1208lmb/london.shtml |title=London Labour Market Monitor |date=January 2009 |publisher=Service Canada |accessdate=19 July 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Since the economic crisis of 2009, which gutted many of London's manufacturing jobs, the city has transitioned to become a technology hub. As of 2016, London is home to 300 technology companies and employs 3% of the city's labor force.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ledc.com/digital-creative|title=LEDC - London Economic Development Corporation|website=LEDC - London Economic Development Corporation|access-date=2016-10-17}} Many of these companies have moved into former factories and industrial spaces located in and around the downtown core, and have renovated them as modern offices. For example, [[Info-Tech Research Group]]'s London office is located in a hosiery factory, and [[Arcane Digital]] moved into a 1930s industrial building in 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lfpress.com/2015/12/13/a-throwback-to-the-steam-engine-era-an-old-downtown-industrial-warehouse-is-debuting-anew-for-the-search-engine-era|title=The Cube: London's newest digital hothouse|last=nurun.com|website=The London Free Press|access-date=2016-10-17}} [[rTraction]], a digital media firm, currently has its offices in [[the London Roundhouse]], a steam locomotive repair shop built in 1887. Its redesign, which opened in 2015, won the 2015 Paul Oberman Award for Adaptive Re-Use from the [[Architectural Conservancy of Ontario]].{{Cite web|url=http://londonroundhouse.com/post/130687606205/lrh-honoured-with-aco-award|title=LRH Honoured with ACO Award|website=The London Roundhouse Project|access-date=2016-10-17}} London is also home to [[Diply]], which is ranked among the top websites on the Internet. The largest employer in London is the [[London Health Sciences Centre]], which employs 10, 555 people.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ledc.com/resources/business-directory|title=LEDC - London Economic Development Corporation|website=LEDC - London Economic Development Corporation|access-date=2016-10-17}} The headquarters of the Canadian division of [[3M]] are located in London. The [[London Life Insurance Company]] was founded there,{{cite web| url=http://www.londonlife.com/002/Home/CorporateInformation/CompanyOverview/index.htm| title=Corporate Information: Company Overview| year=2006| publisher=London Life| accessdate=19 July 2009}} as was [[Imperial Oil]],{{cite web| title=Our History| url=http://www.imperialoil.ca/Canada-English/Imports/history/about_who_history.aspx| accessdate=22 September 2014}} [[GoodLife Fitness]], and both the [[Labatt]] and [[Carling]] breweries. The [[Libro Financial Group]] was founded in London 1951 and is the second largest [[credit union]] in Ontario and employs over 550 people.{{cite web| title=Introducing the New Libro Credit Union| url=https://www.libro.ca/Community/About.aspx| publisher=Libro Credit Union| accessdate=22 September 2014}} [[Canada Trust]] was also founded in London in 1864.{{cite book| title=Canada Trust| url=http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/canada-trust/| first1=Alix| last1=Granger| first2=Eric W.| last2=Daly| work=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]| date=7 February 2006| accessdate=22 September 2014}} [[File:London Life Headquarters.jpg|thumb|London Life's Headquarters in Downtown London]] [[General Dynamics Land Systems]] builds [[armoured personnel carrier]]s in the city.{{cite press release |url=http://www.generaldynamics.com/news/press-releases/detail.cfm?customel_dataPageID_1811=9003 |title=General Dynamics Awarded $5 Million Contract to Perform Engineering Studies in Support of Mobile Gun System |date=22 October 2004 |publisher=General Dynamics Land Systems |accessdate=22 September 2014}} GDLS has a 14-year $15-billion deal to supply light armoured vehicles to [[Saudi Arabia]].{{cite web | url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-politics/union-asks-ndp-to-keep-saudi-armoured-vehicles-deal-under-wraps-fearing-significant-job-losses | title=Union asks NDP to keep Saudi armoured vehicles deal ‘under wraps,’ fearing ‘significant’ job losses | work=Postmedia Network | date=30 September 2015 | accessdate=30 September 2015 | author=De Bono, Norman}} There are 2,400 workers at GDLS Canada. [[McCormick & Company|McCormick Canada]], formerly Club House Foods, was founded in 1883 and currently employs more than 600 Londoners. London's fledgling city centre mall, previously known as Galleria, was purchased and renamed to Citi Plaza by [[Citigroup]] in 2009. Citi Plaza has been redeveloped as a mixed use complex that blends retail, office, businesses, and education providers. Alongside Citi Cards Canada's offices, the complex is also home to London's [[London Public Library|central library]] branch, and satellite campuses for both [[Fanshawe College]] and [[University of Western Ontario|Western University]]. A portion of the city's population work in factories outside of the city limits, including the [[General Motors]] automotive plant [[CAMI Automotive|CAMI]], and a [[Toyota]] plant in [[Woodstock, Ontario|Woodstock]]. A [[St. Thomas Assembly|Ford plant]] in [[Southwold, Ontario|Talbotville]] became one of the casualties of the [[Automotive industry crisis of 2008–10|economic crisis]] in 2011.{{cite news| title=Ontario Ford plant closure brings tears| url=http://www.torontosun.com/2011/09/16/ontario-ford-plant-closure-brings-tears| last=DeBono| first=Norman| date=16 September 2011| work=[[Toronto Sun]]| agency=[[Québecor Média]]| accessdate=22 September 2014}} 11 December 2009, [[Minister of State (Canada)|Minister of State]] [[Gary Goodyear]] announced a new $11-million cargo terminal at the [[London International Airport]].{{cite news| url=http://www.lfpress.com/news/london/2009/12/01/11988566-sun.html| accessdate=22 September 2014| title=London lands freight centre| newspaper=London Free Press| last=Dubinski| first=Kate| date=1 December 2009}} == Culture == {{see also|Media in London, Ontario}} === Festivals === The city is home to many festivals including [[Sunfest (London, Ontario)|Sunfest]], the [[Home County Folk Festival]], the [[London Fringe Theatre Festival (Ontario)|London Fringe Theatre Festival]], the [[Expressions in Chalk Street Painting Festival]], [[Rock the Park]], [[Western Fair]], Dundas Street Festival, and The International Food Festival. [[The London Rib-Fest]] is the second largest barbecue rib festival in North America.{{cite web|url=http://www.festivalsontario.com/|title=Ribfest|publisher=Family Shows Canada|accessdate=24 September 2009}} Pride London Festival is the 11th largest Pride festival in Ontario.{{cite web|url=http://www.pridelondon.ca/|title=Pride London Festival|publisher=Pride London Festival|accessdate=24 September 2009}} [[Sunfest (London, Ontario)|Sunfest]], a [[World music]] festival, is the second biggest in Canada after [[Caribana|Toronto Caribbean Carnival (Caribana)]] in Toronto, and is among the top 100 summer destinations in North America.{{cite web|url=http://www.sunfest.on.ca/|title=About Sunfest|publisher=Sunfest|accessdate=24 September 2009}} === Music === [[Orchestra London Canada]] was a professional symphony orchestra founded in London in 1937. Although the organization filed for bankruptcy in 2015, members of the orchestra continue to play self-produced concerts under the moniker [[Orchestra London Canada|#WePlayOn]]. As of October 2016, the group is surveying the community for ideas about a new name and brand for the ensemble.{{Cite web|url=https://musiciansorchestralondon.wordpress.com/2016/10/05/weplayon-this-autumn/|title=#WePlayOn this Autumn|last=musiciansorchestralondon|date=2016-10-05|website=#WePlayOn|access-date=2016-10-18}} London is also home to the [[London Community Orchestra]], the London Youth Symphony, and the [[Amabile Choirs of London, Canada]]. London also has a rich history in underground music. Noise pioneers, the [[Nihilist Spasm Band]] were formed in the city in 1965. Between 1966 and 1971, the group held a Monday night residency at the York Hotel in the city's core, which established it as a popular venue for emerging musicians and artists. Now known as Call the Office, the venue served as a hotbed for punk music in the late 1970s and 1980s, and continues to host college rock bands and weekly alternative music nights. In 2003, [[CHRW-FM]] developed the London Music Archives, an online music database that chronicles every album recorded in London between 1967 and 2006.{{Cite web|url=http://chrwradio.com/lma/|title=94.9 CHRW - London Music Archive|website=chrwradio.com|access-date=2016-10-18}} London's performance venues include [[Aeolian Hall (London, Ontario)|Aeolian Hall]], a former Victorian-era town hall located in Old East Village, and the [[London Music Hall]], a multi-level performance space in the downtown's Entertainment & Culture District. [[File:795 Dundas Aeolean Hall.jpg|thumb|left|Aeolian Hall]] [[Guy Lombardo]], an internationally-acclaimed big band leader, was born in London, as was jazz musician [[Rob McConnell]]. Contemporary musicians born in London include hip hop artist and former [[CBC Radio]] host, [[Shad (rapper)|Shad]], and singer-songwriter [[Meaghan Smith]]. [[Justin Bieber|Justin Beiber]] was born in London prior to moving to [[Stratford, Ontario]]. === Art === The city is home to several museums, including [[Museum London]], which is located at the [[Thames River (Ontario)|Forks of the Thames]]. Museum London exhibits art by a wide variety of local, regional and national artists.{{cite web| url=http://www.londonmuseum.on.ca/d.aspx?s=/About_Us/default.htm| title=About Us| publisher=Museum London| accessdate=25 September 2009}} London is also home to the [[Museum of Ontario Archaeology]], owned by [[University of Western Ontario|Western University]]. Its main feature is Canada's only on-going excavation and partial reconstruction of a prehistoric village of the [[Neutral Nation]] ([[Lawson Site]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.uwo.ca/museum/|title=Museum of Ontario Archaeology|publisher=University of Western Ontario|accessdate=25 September 2009}} [[The Royal Canadian Regiment Museum]] is a military museum located at [[Wolseley Barracks]], a former Canadian Forces Base in the city's Carling neighbourhood. The [[Secrets of Radar Museum]] was opened at Parkwood Hospital in 2003, and tells the story of the more than 6,000 Canadian [[World War II]] veterans who were recruited into a top-secret project during [[World War II]] involving [[radar]]. The [[London Regional Children's Museum]], located in South London, provides hands-on learning experiences for children and was one of the first children's museums established in Canada. The [[Canadian Medical Hall of Fame]] has its headquarters in downtown London and features a medical history museum. [[File:Museum London.jpg|thumb|Museum London is located at the Forks of the Thames River]] [[Eldon House]] is the former residence of the prominent Harris Family and oldest surviving such building in London. The entire property was donated to the city of London in 1959 and is now a [[heritage site]]. An Ontario Historical Plaque was erected by the province to commemorate The Eldon House's role in Ontario's heritage.{{cite web|url=http://www.ontarioplaques.com/Plaques_MNO/Plaque_Middlesex13.html|title=Eldon House Historical Plaque|year=2005|publisher=Archives of Ontario|accessdate=24 September 2009}} The Banting House National Historic Site of Canada is the house where [[Sir Frederick Banting]] thought of the idea that led to the discovery of [[insulin]]. Banting lived and practiced in London for ten months, from July 1920 to May 1921. London is also the site of the Flame of Hope, which is intended to burn until a cure for [[diabetes]] is discovered.{{cite web|url=http://www.diabetes.ca/about-us/who/banting-house/banting-square/|title=Sir Frederick G. Banting Square|publisher=Canadian Diabetes Association|accessdate=25 September 2009}} London is also home to a number of art galleries and artist spaces including the McIntosh Gallery at [[University of Western Ontario|Western University]], and the London ARTS Project; a gallery, studio, and theatre space located on Dundas Street in the city's Entertainment & Culture District. The [[Forest City Gallery]], co-founded by [[Greg Curnoe]] in 1973, is one of Canada's first artist run centres. It is currently located in the SoHo neighbourhood, south of downtown. London also hosts an annual [[Nuit Blanche]] each June. === Theatre === [[File:710 Dundas Palace Theatre.jpg|thumb|The Palace Theatre is located in Old East Village, east of downtown.]] London is home to the [[Grand Theatre, Ontario|Grand Theatre]], a professional [[proscenium arch]] theatre located in Central London. The building underwent renovations in 1975 to restore the stage's proscenium arch and to add a secondary performance space. The architectural firm responsible for the re-design was awarded a [[Governor General's Awards|Governor General's award]] in 1978 for their work on the venue. In addition to professional productions, the Grand Theatre also hosts the High School Project, a program unique to North America that provides high school students an opportunity to work with professional [[Theatre director|directors]], [[choreographer]]s, [[musical director]]s, and [[stage managers]]. The Palace Theatre, located in Old East Village, originally opened as a silent movie theatre in 1929 and was converted to a live theatre venue in 1991.{{Cite web|url=http://www.palacetheatre.ca/history-of-the-palace/|title=History of The Palace|website=The Palace Theatre|access-date=2016-10-18}} It is currently the home of the [[London Community Players]], and as of 2016 is undergoing extensive historical restoration. The Original Kids Theatre Company, a nonprofit charitable youth organization, currently puts on productions at the Spriet Family Theatre in the Covent Garden Market.{{Cite web|url=http://originalkids.ca/our-history.html|title=Our History|website=Original Kids Theatre Company|access-date=2016-10-18}} === Literature === London serves a core setting in [[Southern Ontario Gothic]] literature, most notably in the works of [[James Reaney]]. Modern writers include fantasy writer [[Kelley Armstrong]], [[Man Booker Prize]] winner, [[Eleanor Catton]], and [[Scotiabank Giller Prize]] nominee, [[Joan Barfoot]]. [[Emma Donoghue]], whose 2010 novel, [[Room (novel)|''Room'']], was adapted into a [[Room (2015 film)|2015 Academy Award winning film]] of the same name, also lives in London. Words is an annual literary and creative arts festival that takes place each November.{{Cite web|url=http://wordsfest.ca/locations|title=Wordsfest|website=wordsfest.ca|access-date=2016-10-18}} === Livability === [[File:Thames River Springbank Park.jpg|thumb|left|Springbank Park, located along the Thames River, is London's largest park]] London's recent [[Urban renewal|urban regeneration]] efforts and civic initiatives have allowed the city to rank high in Canadian livability lists. In 2016, [[MoneySense]] magazine ranked London as the fourth best large Canadian city to live in.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lfpress.com/2016/06/26/scandals-aside-london-ranks-high-as-place-to-live|title=Scandals aside, London ranks high as place to live|last=nurun.com|website=The London Free Press|access-date=2016-10-19}} It also ranked fourth (fifteenth overall) in 2013, and fifth in 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lfpress.com/2013/03/20/london-climbs-to-15th-spot-in-annual-moneysense-magazine-ranking|title=London soars in ranking of best places to live|last=nurun.com|website=The London Free Press|access-date=2016-10-19}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.moneysense.ca/canadas-best-places-to-live-2015-full-ranking/|title=Canada’s Best Places to Live 2015: Full Ranking|newspaper=MoneySense|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-19}} In 2015, London was ranked as the sixth happiest city in Canada by Jetpac City Guides.{{Cite news|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1081134/25-happiest-cities-in-canada/|title=25 happiest cities in Canada|last=Gilligan|first=Melissa|newspaper=Global News|access-date=2016-10-19}} The [[Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives]] ranked London as the sixth best place to be a woman in 2015{{Cite web|url=http://www.lfpress.com/2015/07/15/survey-by-canadian-centre-for-policy-alternatives-gives-london-high-marks-as-a-city-for-women|title=The best place to be a woman in Ontario? London|last=nurun.com|website=The London Free Press|access-date=2016-10-19}} and third in 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/what-is-the-best-and-worst-city-in-canada-to-be-a-woman-1.3113113|title=What is the best and worst city in Canada to be a woman?|newspaper=CTVNews|access-date=2016-10-19}} The city's cost of living is low compared to other southern Ontario cities. According to the London St. Thomas Association of Realtors, the average price of a home in the London and [[St. Thomas, Ontario|St. Thomas]] area in 2016 is $274,383, which is substantially lower than the national average of $467,082. It is also well below the average home prices of nearby cities including [[Toronto]] ($736,670), [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]] ($510,204), and [[Kitchener-Waterloo]] ($364,290).{{Cite web|url=http://www.lstar.ca/news/best-september-ever-0|title=Best September EVER {{!}} London St. Thomas Association of Realtors|website=www.lstar.ca|access-date=2016-10-19}} The 2015 average rental rate for a one-bedroom apartment is $781. London has nine major parks and gardens throughout the city, many of which run along the [[Thames River (Ontario)|Thames River]] and are interconnected by a series of pedestrian and bike paths, known as the Thames Valley Parkway.{{Cite web|url=https://www.london.ca/residents/Parks/Explore-Parks/Pages/Major-Parks-Gardens.aspx|title=Major Parks and Gardens|website=www.london.ca|access-date=2016-10-19}} This path system is 40 km (25 mi) in length, and connects to an additional 150 km (93 mi) of bike and hiking trails throughout the city.{{Cite web|url=https://www.london.ca/residents/Parks/Explore-Parks/Pages/Thames-Valley-Parkway.aspx|title=Thames Valley Parkway|website=www.london.ca|access-date=2016-10-19}} The city's largest park, [[Springbank Park]], is 140-hectare (300 acre) and contains 30 km (19 mi) of trails. It is also home to Storybook Gardens, a family attraction open year round. == Sports == [[File:London vs Hamilton.jpg|thumb|London Majors, Spring 2008]] London is currently the home of the [[London Knights]] of the [[Ontario Hockey League]], who play at the [[Budweiser Gardens]] (previously known as the John Labatt Centre). The Knights are 2004-2005 and 2015-2016 OHL and [[Memorial Cup]] Champions.{{cite web| url=http://johnlabattcentre.com/generalinfo-history.html| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713113754/http://johnlabattcentre.com/generalinfo-history.html| archivedate=13 July 2011| title=History| publisher=John Labatt Centre| accessdate=5 April 2012}} During the summer months, the [[London Majors]] of the [[Intercounty Baseball League]] play at [[Labatt Park]]. [[London City (soccer club)|London City]] of the [[Canadian Soccer League (current)|Canadian Soccer League]], is the highest level of soccer in London. Other sports teams include the London Silver Dolphins Swim Team, the Forest City Volleyball Club, London Cricket Club, the London St. George's Rugby Club, the London Aquatics Club, the London Rhythmic Gymnastics Club, London City Soccer Club and [[Forest City London]]. Football teams include the London Beefeaters (Ontario Football Conference). London's basketball team, the [[London Lightning]] plays at [[Budweiser Gardens]] as members of the [[National Basketball League of Canada]]. Finishing their inaugural regular season at 28-8, the Lightning would go on to win the [[2011-12 NBL Canada season|2011-12]] NBL Canada championship, defeating the [[Halifax Rainmen]] in the finals three games to two. There are also a number of former sports teams that have now either moved or folded. London's four former baseball teams are the [[London Monarchs (baseball)|London Monarchs]] ([[Canadian Baseball League]]), the [[London Werewolves]] ([[Frontier League]]), the [[London Tecumsehs]] ([[International Association (baseball)|International Association]]) and the [[London Tigers]] (AA [[Eastern League (U.S. baseball)|Eastern League]]). Other former sports teams include the London Lasers ([[Canadian Soccer League (1987–1992)|Canadian Soccer League]]) and the [[London Nationals]] (Western Ontario Hockey League). In March 2013, London hosted the [[2013 World Figure Skating Championships]]. [[File:Zach Harnden Western Mustangs.jpg|thumb|Zach Harnden of the [[Western Ontario Mustangs men's ice hockey|Western Mustangs]]]] The University of Western Ontario teams play under the name ''Mustangs''. Fanshawe College teams play under the name ''Falcons''. The Women's Cross Country team has won 3 consecutive [[Canadian Collegiate Athletic Association]] (CCAA) National Championships.{{cite web| url=http://www.ccaa.ca/lethbridge-runners-cross-the-finish-line-first-at-the-2008-ccaa-cross-country-running-open-p185913| title=Lethbridge Runners cross the finish line first at the 2008 CCAA Cross Country Running Open| date=June 2009| publisher=CCAA| accessdate=22 September 2014}} In 2010, the program cemented itself as the first CCAA program to win both Men's and Women's National team titles, as well as CCAA Coach of the Year.{{cite web| url=http://www.ccaa.ca/web/index.php/en/cc-news-archive/601-alberta-runners-top-2010-ccaa-cross-country-running-nationals| title=Alberta Runners Top 2010 CCAA Cross Country Running Nationals| publisher=CCAA| accessdate=5 April 2012}} The Western Fair Raceway, about 85 acres [[harness racing]] track and simulcast centre, operates year-round.{{cite web| url=http://www.westernfair.com/race/home.html| title=Western Fair Raceway| year=2006| publisher=Western Fair Entertainment Centre| accessdate=27 September 2009}} The grounds include a coin slot [[casino]], a former [[IMAX]] theatre, and Sports and Agri-complex. [[Matt Brown (Canadian politician)|Matt Brown]] was elected mayor in the [[London, Ontario municipal election, 2014|2014 municipal election]], officially taking office {{as of|2014|12|1|alt=on 1 December 2014}}.[http://london.ctvnews.ca/matt-brown-elected-as-new-mayor-of-london-1.2074064 "Matt Brown elected as new mayor of London"]. [[CFPL-DT|CTV London]], 27 October 2014. Prior to Brown's election, London's [[List of mayors of London, Ontario|most recent elected mayor]] was [[Joe Fontana]]; following Fontana's resignation on 19 June 2014, city councillor Joe Swan served as [[acting mayor]]{{cite news| url=http://www.torontosun.com/2014/06/19/joe-fontana-officially-resigns-as-mayor-of-london| title=Joe Fontana officially resigns as mayor of London| work=Toronto Sun| date=19 June 2014| last=Maloney| first=Patrick| accessdate=22 September 2014}} until councillor Joni Baechler was selected as interim mayor 24 June.{{cite news| title=London, Ont. names new mayor to replace Fontana| url=http://www.torontosun.com/2014/06/24/london-ont-names-new-mayor-to-replace-fontana| work=Toronto Sun| date=24 June 2014| agency=Québecor Média| last=Maloney| first=Patrick| accessdate=22 September 2014}} Until the elections in 2010, there was a [[Board of Control (municipal government)|Board of Control]], consisting of four controllers and the mayor, all elected city-wide.{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/City_Council/default.htm| title=Your December 2006 - November 2010 Council| year=2006| publisher=City of London| accessdate=27 September 2009}} The composition of [[London City Council]] was challenged by two ballot questions during the civic election of 2003. A proposal to restructure the municipal government would have reduced the council to ten wards and eliminated the Board of Control. The council could not come to a determination and as a result decided to put two questions on the ballot for the fall 2003 election: whether city council should be reduced in size and whether the Board of Control should be eliminated. While the "yes" votes prevailed in both instances, the [[voter turnout]] failed to exceed 50 per cent and was therefore insufficient to make the decisions binding under the ''Municipal Act''. When the council voted to retain the [[status quo]], Imagine London, a citizens group, petitioned the [[Ontario Municipal Board]] (OMB) to change the ward composition of the city from seven wards in a roughly [[wikt:radial|radial]] pattern from the downtown core, to 14 wards defined by [[community of interest|communities of interest]].{{cite web| url=http://www.omb.gov.on.ca/e-decisions/pl050623_%233072.pdf| title=PL050623| date=November 2005| publisher=Ontario Municipal Board| accessdate=27 September 2009}} The OMB ruled for the petitioners in December 2005 and, while the city sought leave to appeal the OMB decision via the courts, leave was denied on 28 February 2006, in a decision of Superior Court's Justice McDermid.{{cite news| title=Judge rejects ward appeal| last=Sher| first=Jonathan| date=1 March 2006| publisher=London Free Press}} In response, the city conceded change, but asked for special legislation from the province to ensure that there will only be one councillor in each of the 14 new wards, not two. 1 June 2006, the Ontario bill received [[Royal Assent|royal assent]], which guarantees that London will have one councillor per ward.{{cite web |url=http://www.ontla.on.ca/web/bills/bills_detail.do?BillID=419&isCurrent=false| title=An Act respecting the City of London| date=June 2006| publisher=Government of Ontario| accessdate=22 September 2014}} Although London has many ties to Middlesex County, it is now "separated" and the two have no jurisdictional overlap. The exception is the Middlesex County courthouse and former jail, as the judiciary is administered directly by the province.{{cite web| url=http://www.county.middlesex.on.ca/CountyInformation/About_Middlesex.asp| title=Middlesex County Information| publisher=Middlesex County| accessdate=27 September 2009}} In the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario|provincial government]], London is represented by [[Ontario Liberal Party|Liberal]] [[Deb Matthews]] ([[London North Centre (provincial electoral district)|London North Centre]]); [[Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario|Progressive Conservative]] [[Jeff Yurek]] ([[Elgin—Middlesex—London (provincial electoral district)|Elgin—Middlesex—London]]), and [[Ontario New Democratic Party|NDPs]]: [[Teresa Armstrong]] ([[London—Fanshawe (provincial electoral district)|London—Fanshawe]]) and [[Peggy Sattler]] ([[London West (provincial electoral district)|London West]]).{{cite web| url=http://www.ontla.on.ca/web/members/members_current.do?locale=en&ord=Riding&dir=ASC&list_type=all_mpps| title=Current MPPs| publisher=Legislative Assembly of Ontario| accessdate=26 October 2013}} In the [[Canadian House of Commons|federal government]], London is represented by Conservative [[Karen Vecchio]] ([[Elgin—Middlesex—London]]), Liberals [[Peter Fragiskatos]] ([[London North Centre]]) and [[Kate Young (politician)|Kate Young]] (London West), and NDP [[Irene Mathyssen]] ([[London—Fanshawe]]).{{cite web| url=http://webinfo.parl.gc.ca/MembersOfParliament/MainMPsCompleteList.aspx?TimePeriod=Current&Language=E| title=Members of Parliament| publisher=Parliament of Canada| accessdate=7 June 2011}} [[File:Downtown London Zoom.jpg|thumb|Right|[[Urban consolidation]] is a key strategy for London, helping to curb low-density greenfield expansion and revitalize the downtown, similar to the [[London Plan]] in [[Greater London, England]].]] In 2001, the City of London first published their [[Facilities Accessibility Design Standards (FADS)]] which was one of the first North American municipal [[accessibility]] requirements to include [[Universal Design]]. It has since been adopted by over 50 municipalities in [[Canada]] and the [[United States]].{{cite web| url=https://www.london.ca/city-hall/accessibility/Pages/Facilities-Accessibility-Design-Standards.aspx| title=Facilities Accessibility Design Standards (FADS)| year=2016| publisher=City of London Ontario| accessdate=20 August 2016}} === Serial killing === Between 1959 and 1984, London contained the largest concentration of [[serial killers]] in the world, as the city was startled by 29 murders. During that time period, up to six serial killers may have been operating in London,{{cite web | last = Suen | first = Fan-Yee | title = Serial-Killer Capital of the World? A Look at London, Ont.'s Dark History | publisher = CTV News | date = March 10, 2014 | url = http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/serial-killer-capital-of-the-world-a-look-at-london-ont-s-dark-history-1.1721931}} though three were convicted for 13 of the killings: Gerald Thomas Archer (the "London Chamber Maid Slayer"), Christian Magee (the "Mad Slasher") and Russell Johnson (the "Balcony Killer"), with the other 16 murders still unsolved as of August 2015.[http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/19/serial-killer-london-ontario-canada Files shed light on unsolved deaths in former 'serial killer capital' of the world] - The Guardian === Civic initiatives === The City of London initiatives in Old East London are helping to create a renewed sense of vigour in the East London Business District. Specific initiatives include the creation of the Old East Heritage Conservation District under Part V of the ''Ontario Heritage Act'', special Building Code policies and Facade Restoration Programs.{{cite web| url=http://www.oldeastvillage.com/pdf_reports/Re-establishingValue-aPlanfortheOldEastVillage.pdf| title=Re-establishing Value| publisher=Ontario Professional Planners Institute| accessdate=17 July 2009}} London is home to heritage properties representing a variety of [[architectural style]]s,{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/d.aspx?s=/Heritage/HeritageCitymap.htm| title=Heritage Inventory| publisher=City of London| accessdate=24 September 2009}} including [[Queen Anne Style architecture|Queen Anne]], [[Art Deco]], [[Modern movement|Modern]], and [[Brutalist architecture|Brutalist]] Londoners have become protective of the trees in the city, protesting "unnecessary" removal of trees.{{cite web| url=http://www.londonkiosk.ca/london-tourism.php| title=London Tourism Information| year=2009| publisher=London Kiosk| accessdate=27 September 2009}} The City Council and tourist industry have created projects to replant trees throughout the city. As well, they have begun to erect metal trees of various colours in the downtown area, causing some controversy.{{cite news| url=http://www.gazette.uwo.ca/pdf/Gazette-2008-09-30.pdf| title=Metal Tree Planting Continues| last=Haggarty| first=Jaclyn| date=30 September 2008 |newspaper=UWO Gazette| page=1| accessdate=21 October 2009}} == Transportation == {{see also|List of roads in London, Ontario}} === Road transportation === [[File:Highway 401 from Wellington Road in London, Looking West Towards Highway 402.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ontario Highway 401|Highway 401]] in London looking towards [[Ontario Highway 402|Highway 402]] from [[Wellington Road (London, Ontario)|Wellington Road]]]] London is at the junction of [[Ontario Highway 401|Highway 401]] that connects the city to Toronto and Detroit, and [[Ontario Highway 402|Highway 402]] to [[Sarnia]].{{cite web| url=http://goodmovelondon.com/gettingto/| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080503121435/http://goodmovelondon.com/gettingto/| archivedate=3 May 2008| title=Getting to London| year=2006| publisher=LEDC| accessdate=27 September 2009}}{{cite web| url=http://www.mto.gov.on.ca/english/news/regional/2000/2000-0001.shtml| title=Ontario government improving Highway 402 between London and Sarnia| year=2009| publisher=Government of Ontario| accessdate=27 September 2009}} Also, [[Ontario Highway 403|Highway 403]], which diverges from the 401 at nearby [[Woodstock, Ontario]], provides ready access to [[Brantford]], [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]], the [[Golden Horseshoe]] area, and the [[Niagara Peninsula]].{{cite web| url=http://www.thekingshighway.ca/Highway403.htm| title=The King's Highway 403| last=Bevers| first=Cameron| year=2002| accessdate=27 September 2009}} Many smaller two-lane [[highway]]s also pass through or near London, including [[King's Highways in Ontario|Kings Highway]]s [[Ontario Highway 2|2]], [[Ontario Highway 3|3]], [[Ontario Highway 4|4]], [[Ontario Highway 7|7]] and 22. Many of these are "historical" names, as provincial downloading in the 1980s and 1990s put responsibility for most provincial highways on municipal governments.{{cite web| url=http://www.thekingshighway.ca/Highway24.htm| title=The King's Highway 24| last=Bevers| first=Cameron| year=2002| accessdate=27 September 2009}} Nevertheless, these roads continue to provide access from London to nearby communities and locations in much of [[Western Ontario]], including [[Goderich, Ontario|Goderich]], [[Port Stanley, Ontario|Port Stanley]] and [[Owen Sound]]. [[File:Veterans Memorial Parkway, London, Ontario.jpg|thumb|left|Intersection along the [[Veterans Memorial Parkway]], an at-grade [[limited-access road|expressway]]]] Since the 1970s, London has improved urban road alignments that eliminated "jogs" in established traffic patterns over 19th-century street mis-alignments. The lack of a municipal [[freeway]] (either through or around the city) as well as the presence of two significant railways (each with attendant switching yards and few over/under-passes) are the primary causes of [[rush hour]] congestion, along with construction and heavy snow. Thus, traffic times can be significantly variable, although major traffic jams are rare.{{cite web| url=http://www.london.ca/city-hall/master-plans-reports/master-plans/Documents/Transportation%20Master%20Plan.pdf| title=Transportation Master Plan| date=May 2013| publisher=City of London| pages=2–23| accessdate=17 December 2013}} Wellington Road between Commissioners Road E and Southdale Road E is London's busiest section of roadway, with more than 46,000 vehicles using the span on an average day{{cite web| title= City of London Traffic Volume Data| author=City of London| date=2013| url=http://www.london.ca/residents/Roads-Transportation/traffic-management/Pages/Traffic-Volumes.aspx| accessdate=26 October 2011}} City council rejected early plans for the construction of a freeway, and instead accepted the [[Veterans Memorial Parkway]] to serve the east end.{{cite web| title=Long-Term Transportation Corridor Protection Study| publisher=City of London| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130913040755/http://london.ca/d.aspx?s=/Transportation/corridorstudy.htm| archivedate=13 September 2013| url=http://london.ca/d.aspx?s=/Transportation/corridorstudy.htm| accessdate=17 December 2013}} Some Londoners have expressed concern that the absence of a local freeway may hinder London's economic and population growth, while others have voiced concern that such a freeway would destroy environmentally sensitive areas and further contribute to London's suburban sprawl. Road capacity improvements have been made to Veterans Memorial Parkway (formerly named Airport Road and [[Highway 100 (Ontario)|Highway 100]]) in the industrialized east end.{{cite web| archivedate=7 August 2007| title=King's Highway 401 - Images| last=Steeves| first=Scott| year=2004| url=http://www.onthighways.com/hwy_401_images/Hwy401_p4_images.htm| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807234534/http://onthighways.com/hwy_401_images/Hwy401_p4_images.htm| accessdate=28 September 2009}} However, the Parkway has received criticism for not being built as a proper highway; a recent city-run study suggested upgrading it by replacing the intersections with interchanges.{{cite web| title=Veterans Memorial Parkway| year=2007| publisher=City of London| url=http://www.london.ca/residents/Environment/EAs/Documents/VMP-PicBoard2.pdf| accessdate=17 December 2013}} === Public transit === [[File:London Transit New Flyer.jpg|thumb|London Transit Commission Bus]] London's [[Public transport|public transit]] system is run by the [[London Transit|London Transit Commission]], which has 44 bus routes throughout the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.ltconline.ca/Routes.htm|title=Routes and Schedules|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=London Transit Commission|accessdate=19 October 2016}} Although the city has lost ridership over the last few years, the commission is making concerted efforts to enhance services by implementing a five year improvement plan. In 2015, an additional 17,000 hours of bus service was added throughout the city. In 2016, 11 new operators, 5 new busses, and another 17,0000 hours of bus service were added to the network.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lfpress.com/2016/08/16/more-hours-new-names-for-routes-coming-next-month-as-overhaul-of-the-london-transit-commission-enters-next-phase|title=LTC rolling out big changes|last=nurun.com|website=The London Free Press|access-date=2016-10-19}} Bus service is currently the only mode of public transit available to the public in London, with no available [[rapid transit]] networks like those used in other Canadian cities. However, city council approved a [[bus rapid transit]] (BRT) business case in May 2016 that will see a rapid transit system running in L- and 7-shaped corridors throughout the city. Construction is expected to begin in 2018, with the service fully operational by 2025.{{Cite news|url=http://www.shiftlondon.ca/timeline|title=Timeline|newspaper=Shift|access-date=2016-10-19}} London does have several [[taxicab|taxi]] and for-hire [[limousine]] services. [[File:Bike Lane Wortley.jpg|thumb|left|A separated bike lane in Wortley Village]] === Cycling network === London has 330 km (205 mi) of cycling paths throughout the city, 91 km (59 mi) of which have been added since 2005.{{Cite web|url=https://www.londonbikes.ca/document/1-new-updated-london-bikes-executive-summary|title=#1: NEW- Updated London ON Bikes Executive Summary {{!}} City of London Cycling Master Plan Update|website=www.londonbikes.ca|access-date=2016-10-19}} In June 2016, London unveiled its first bike corrals, which replace parking for one vehicle with fourteen bicycle parking spaces, and fix-it stations, which provide cyclists with simple tools and a bicycle pump, throughout the city.{{Cite web|url=https://www.london.ca/newsroom/Pages/bike-carrols.aspx|title=City Unveils London’s First Ever Bike Corrals and New Fix-it Stations|website=www.london.ca|access-date=2016-10-19}} In September 2016, city council approved a new 15 year cycling master plan that will see the construction of an additional 470 km (292 mi) of cycling paths added to the existing network.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lfpress.com/2016/09/06/london-bike-path-plan-ready-for-action|title=Cycling plan ready for public test ride|last=nurun.com|website=The London Free Press|access-date=2016-10-19}} === Intercity transport === [[File:VIA Rail Train London Ontario.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Via Rail]] station in downtown London is Canada's fourth busiest railway terminal.]] London is on the [[Canadian National Railway]] main line between Toronto and [[Chicago]] (with a secondary main line to [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]]) and the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] main line between Toronto and Detroit.{{cite web| url=http://www.londonedc.com/forsiteselectors/infrastructure/transportation/| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070809231730/http://www.londonedc.com/forsiteselectors/infrastructure/transportation/| archivedate=9 August 2007| title=Transportation| year=2006| publisher=London Economic Development Corporation| accessdate=28 September 2009}} [[Via Rail]] operates regional passenger service through [[London, Ontario railway station|London station]] as part of the [[Quebec City–Windsor Corridor]], with connections to the [[United States]].{{cite web| url=http://www.viarail.ca/en/stations/ontario/london/routes|title=Train routes to/from London| publisher=Via Rail| accessdate=28 September 2009}} Via Rail's London terminal is the fourth-busiest passenger terminal in Canada. London is also a destination for inter-city [[bus]] travellers. London is the seventh-busiest [[Greyhound Lines|Greyhound Canada]] terminal in terms of passengers,{{cite web| url=http://www.greyhound.ca/HOME/en/About/FactsAndFigures.aspx| title=Facts & Figures| publisher=Greyhound Canada| accessdate=28 September 2009}} and connecting services radiate from London throughout [[Southwestern Ontario]] and through to the American cities of [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] and [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. [[Aboutown Transportation]] is a diversified transportation company based in the city that operates the ''North Link'',{{cite web| url=http://www.aboutown.ca/northlink/index.html| title=Aboutown Northlink| publisher=Aboutown| accessdate=24 September 2009| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080506140347/http://www.aboutown.ca/northlink/index.html| archivedate=6 May 2008}} intercity bus service from [[Owen Sound]], and six transit bus routes between [[King's University College (University of Western Ontario)|Kings]] and [[Brescia University College|Brescia]] Colleges, and the main campus at the University of Western Ontario. [[London International Airport]] ([[IATA airport code|YXU]]) is the 12th busiest passenger airport in Canada and the 11th busiest airport in Canada by take-offs and landings. It is served by airlines including [[Air Canada Jazz]], [[United Airlines]] and [[WestJet]], and provides direct flights to both domestic and international destinations, including Toronto, Chicago, [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Ottawa]], [[Winnipeg]], [[Calgary]] and [[Cancún]].{{cite web| url=http://www.londonairport.on.ca/airlines.html| title=Airlines and Tour Operators| publisher=London International Airport| accessdate=19 February 2011}} === Plans === [[File:London International Airport arrivals outside.jpg|thumb|left|[[London International Airport]]]] The city of London is considering [[bus rapid transit]] (BRT) and/or [[high-occupancy vehicle lane]]s (HOV) to help it achieve its long-term transportation plan. Additional cycleways are planned for integration in road-widening projects, where there is need and sufficient space along routes. An [[limited-access road|expressway]]/freeway network is possible along the eastern and western ends of the city, from [[Ontario Highway 401|Highway 401]] (and [[Ontario Highway 402|Highway 402]] for the western route) past Oxford Street, potentially with another highway, joining the two in the city's north end. The City of London has assessed the entire length of the Veterans Memorial Parkway, identifying areas where interchanges can be constructed, grade separations can occur, and where [[cul-de-sac]]s can be placed. Upon completion, the Veterans Memorial Parkway would no longer be an expressway, but a freeway, for the majority of its length.{{cite web| title= Veterans Memorial Parkway Interchange Class Environmental Assessment Study and Concurrent Application to Amend the Official Plan and Zoning By-Law| author= City of London and Giffels| date= 13 December 2007| url= http://www.london.ca/residents/Environment/EAs/Documents/VMP-PicBoard2.pdf| accessdate=17 December 2013}} A [[high-speed rail]] station has been proposed for London, connecting it to a future high-speed rail line along the Quebec City-Windsor corridor. It would run along the [[Canadian National]] rail right of way through the city.{{cite web| title= Map of Proposed High Speed Rail routes along the Quebec City-Windsor Corridor|author1=Transport Canada |author2=Ontario Ministry of Transportation |author3=Transports Quebec | date= 14 June 2011| url= http://www.mto.gov.on.ca/english/pubs/high-speed-rail/map/254-P020563-112_Localisation_3000000_2010-06-14.pdf| accessdate=25 November 2011}} == Education == [[File:UniversityCollegeUWO.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Middlesex Memorial Tower, University College, [[University of Western Ontario]]]] {{See also|List of schools in London, Ontario}} London public [[Primary education|elementary]] and [[Secondary education|secondary schools]] are governed by four [[Board of education|school boards]] – the [[Thames Valley District School Board]], the [[London District Catholic School Board]] and the French first language school boards (the ''[[Conseil scolaire Viamonde]]'' and the ''[[Conseil scolaire catholique Providence]]'' or CSC). The CSC has a satellite office in London."[http://www.cscprovidence.ca/fr/nous-joindre/3-bureau-satellite-de-london-middlesex Bureau satellite de London / Middlesex]." "Adresse: 920, rue Huron London Ontario N5Y 4K4 Canada" There are also more than twenty private schools in the city.{{cite web| url=http://london.ca/d.aspx?s=/Education/default.htm| title=Education| year=2009| publisher=City of London| accessdate=28 September 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806084408/http://london.ca/d.aspx?s=/Education/default.htm |archivedate=6 August 2013}} London is home to [[London Central Secondary School]], the highest ranking academic school in Ontario.{{cite web |url=http://ontario.compareschoolrankings.org/secondary/SchoolsByRankLocationName.aspx |title=Compare academic rankings and ratings of Ontario schools |website=The Fraser Institute |accessdate=30 November 2013}} The city is home to two [[Higher education|post-secondary]] institutions: the [[University of Western Ontario]] (UWO) and [[Fanshawe College]], a college of applied arts and technology.
